newsitem.title: USA: Microsoft Corp to acquire Dimension X.
newsitem.headline: Microsoft Corp to acquire Dimension X.

text.p: Microsoft Corp on Wednesday said it signed a definitive agreement to acquire Dimension X, a privately held developer of Internet-related software based on the Java developer's language.

In a statement, Microsoft said the acquisition gives it "a set of key products and technologies" to enhance its Internet browser software, Microsoft Internet Explorer, as well as its developer software known as DirectX.

Based in San Francisco, Dimension X created the first Java-based multimedia authoring tool for creating Internet pages, called Liquid Motion, and the first Java-based VRML browser and runtime technology, called Liquid Reality.

By incorporating the line of Liquid products and technology, software developers using Microsoft DirectX will be able to incorporate video, audio, 3-D, 2-D and animation into applications for the Windows operating system.

"With the acquisition of Dimension X, Microsoft will gain powerful Java-based multimedia technology and a team of people who have been working with Java since its inception," said Brad Silverberg, senior vice president of the applications and Internet client group at Microsoft.
Most of Dimension X's 40 employees will join Microsoft in Redmond including Dimension X founders Karl Jacob, Chris Laurel and Ryan Watkins and several of its key engineers.
